title: The Legacy of Call of Duty

rawLines.text: [Music]
Welcome to the Navit Gaming Podcast,
where it is our mission to explore the
business and future of video games. We
bring together the industry's brightest
builders, investors, and thinkers to
keep a pulse on current events, dissect
emerging trends and games, share lessons
learned, and have a great time.
This podcast is also part of Navik's
growing ecosystem which ranges from free
and premium research to consulting and
advisory services. For more information,
visit www.navic.co.
[Music]
This episode is brought to you by Neon.
For the first time in our industry,
developers can finally have their own
DTOC channels to save on app store fees
and build closer relationships with
players. But there's a catch. Selling
direct means either building complex
infrastructure yourself or choosing
among legacy providers whose
inexperience in games or questionable
reputations pose real risk to your
business. Luckily, there's Neon, the
DTOC platform built for games. As a
merchant of record with customizable web
shops optimized for conversion and
modern APIs that let you use your
existing live ops tools, Neon is trusted
by some of the biggest names in gaming
to help you sell direct without the
typical overhead. To start selling
direct and finally take control over
your full player experience, simply head
to neonpay.com
or check out the link in the show notes.
And with that, let's jump into the
episode. Welcome to the Noviet Gaming
Podcast. I'm your host, David Taylor.
The Call of Duty franchise needs no
introduction, but today we're speaking
with a leader who has been there since
it launched in 2003. So, let's do a
quick review. Call of Duty is the
bestselling firstperson shooter
franchise and the second bestselling
video game franchise of all time after
Mario and ahead of Pok√©mon and Tetris.
It reportedly surpassed over 500 million
copies sold in 2023, over 30 billion in
revenue, and maintains a monthly active
user base of 100 million players.
According to the Washington Post, over
the years, there's been three primary
studios working on it. Infinity Ward
created the franchise in the seminal
Modern Warfare series. Treyarch
established zombie modes in World at War
and the popular Black Ops series, and
Sledgehammer Games joined later to
co-develop titles starting in the 2010s.
Today, we're going to dive into Call of
Duty's amazing history through the lens
of Treyarch. With that, I'm thrilled to
be joined by the former studio head of
Treyarch, Dan Bunting, who is now the
founder of Ready UpUp Games and a
venture partner at 1 a.m. Gaming. Dan,
welcome to the podcast. Thank you. Glad
to be here. So, we're going to cover a
lot of your career over the next hour,
but just to kick us off, could you give
a introduction on your journey? How did
you get into the video game industry?
And how did you find yourself at
Treyarch back in 2003 when the COD
franchise was just getting started?
